Add a Sheet to an Excel Workbook with Configurable NA Handling

Source: R/writeNULISAseq.R
add_sheet_to_wb.Rd

This helper function adds a new worksheet to an openxlsx workbook object and writes data to it with customizable handling of NA values. It provides a convenient wrapper around openxlsx::addWorksheet() and openxlsx::writeData() with standardized formatting.

add_sheet_to_wb(
  wb,
  sheet_name,
  data,
  colNames = TRUE,
  na_as_string = FALSE,
  startRow = 1,
  startCol = 1
)

Arguments

wb

An openxlsx workbook object created with openxlsx::createWorkbook()

sheet_name

Character string specifying the name of the worksheet to create

data

A data frame or matrix containing the data to write to the worksheet

colNames

Logical indicating whether to write column names. Default is TRUE

na_as_string

Logical indicating how to handle NA values: - If TRUE, NA values are written as the string "NA" in Excel cells - If FALSE, NA values are written as empty cells in Excel Default is FALSE (empty cells)

startRow

Integer specifying the row number to start writing data. Default is 1

startCol

Integer specifying the column number to start writing data. Default is 1

Value

None. The function modifies the workbook object in place by adding a new worksheet with the specified data.

Details

The function creates a worksheet with gridLines enabled by default. When na_as_string = FALSE, the function uses keepNA = FALSE to ensure NA values appear as empty cells rather than displaying any text. This is particularly useful for detectability and quantifiability table where empty cells are shown as "NA" text.

See also

addWorksheet, writeData
